title: Will Scott Morrison cease to be prime minister of Australia before 1 September 2021?
preds: Short remaining time period. No mention in articles of any specific action toward ousting PM
Can we close this question yet?  There has never been any serious indication that Morrison might be ousted this year.

Of the 35 previous Australian Governments, only 13 have exceeded serving 1105 days (24/8/18 - 31/8/21).
Morrison cease before 1/9/21 = 63% = 22/35 However, with this question reaching its deadline ->
Morrison cease before 1/9/21 = 9% = (22/152) * 63% Combined with the changes to the Liberal Party leadership rules making a coup unlikely, I will reduce ->
Morrison cease before 1/9/21 = 5%

Mortality – 53 relatively young guy in relatively good health. Expected life expectancy at 85 years but I’ll add 5 and then divide chance of death proportionately first before reweighing. - 2.7% and because most deaths happen around the 85ish age, I’ll reweigh to 1%.  https://qsuper.qld.gov.au/calculators-and-forms/calculators/retirement-planning/life-expectancy  Liberal Leadership spill – this would be dependent on two things: 
	whether Scott Morrison can win the election.
		If yes, I ultimately believe he currently can but will need to look at marginal seats.
		If no, why? And then who can?
			Absent leader during bushfires, Covid, disasters
			bungled Covid rollout. 
			Rape allegations within government. 	Whether they agree with his policies.
		Major policy currently are is Covid vaccine rollout.
		Peter Dutton organises another spill. 	I’ll put this at 3%. So totals are: 0.01 mortality, if he survives + 0.99 * (0.008 lose election + 0.03 leadership spill) 
= 0.047. I’ll round up to 0.05. 5%

Those following along would have seen the announcement of the latest "newspoll", I've mentioned this before its the political poll held in the highest regard.  The result was BAD for the LNP and the Morrison government (1).  His party now TRAILS 47-53 in "2 party preferred", and his handling of the pandemic score has dropped to "51% satisfied" (down from a high in the 80s) - this is in a country which has seen a budget surplus in the last 18 months, and had 32k cases with <1k deaths due to Covid.  This has been at a very high price with the inconsistencies we've seen everywhere else, but a MUCH better result.  Why it doesn't impact this question?  He's heavily preferred as PM compared to the leader of the opposition, so it would be a true bolt from the blue if he was rolled.  So, he still needs to call an election, and given this newspoll result it's going to be a tough sell to go early.  And, we're now past the point of no return anyway, even if an election was announced today, it's logistically impossible for polling to occur before the end of August (2). 1. https://www.news.com.au/national/politics/coalition-loses-ground-amid-slow-vaccine-rollout-newspoll/news-story/4d009ba02a6daaebac66a1b12747681a
2. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1260326

I previously outlined detail on the time it takes between announcement and delivery of an election (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1260326), so we only really have about 4 weeks in this question before an election is no longer a factor.  The Nats spill will only cement the need to let this blow over before calling an election, I think the LNP will be looking for a early 2021 election and praying for a gentle bushfire season.  That date allows for Australia to forget this spill; we SHOULD have enough vaccines in people to forget about how awful that rollout has been; they can probably commit to a date for opening the boarder; and claim a big win on the economy from the mid-year budget (we'll assume resources prices stay astronomical for at least 1 more quarter, also noting our tax year is July-June, so January is the "mid-year" budget).

The recent change in the Nationals leadership on 21st June increases the probability of a misstep either with his Coalition partner and/or on climate policy. Such a misstep has the potential to put the majority of his colleagues offside and result in his removal as Liberal leader and Prime Minister. While it's very unlikely that this series of events would occur in such a short period of time, particularly with Scott Morrison who seems adept at maintaining loyalty within the Liberal party, it should never be discounted in Australian politics these days. Several Australian leaders have been voted out recently by their party room on almost that little.

Beyond a lot of valid opinion in here, short of death, there is 2 procedural hurdles that makes this outcome extremely unlikely.  I don't think our PM will be rolled, for the non-Australians, this mean replaced by his own party. We elect parties here and not PMs, and as a result a party can replace their leader following their own internal rules. This was part of the infrastructure that resulted in 10 prime ministerial terms in 11 years. As a result of this the LNP (Scott Morrison's Party) has adjusted their party room rules to require a two-thirds majority vote from there elected representatives (1) in order to overturn their leader.  We also need to consider the build up and the time taken to undertake a spill motion. 4 days for the last spill (2), but months in plotting and disappointing public polling is normally the build up - newspoll is the obsession for anyone interested, and he was leading 52-32 as preffered PM (3) last week. His approval rating is too high and the two-thirds majority insulates him too well for a spill to be realistically considered.  Next we have to consider an election. We don't have fixed term parliaments, and thanks to vaccine rollout delays (4), and what feels like a never ending festival of misogyny that is the LNP at the moment, I would think it's unlikely he will call one until long after we begin rolling out homemade Covid vaccines.  And even if he does call an election soon, we need to follow electoral procedure (5). The our final polling day falls on a Saturday somewhere between 41 - 75 days after calling the election which is marked by the dissolution of parliament. The latest this polling day that can resolve this as a yes is Saturday August 28th, and even that assumes a near immediate result. So for this to resolve as yes, he has until Friday July 16 to call the election at the latest, to then lose that by a landslide. More likely, there will be acceptable delays in the procedural steps and counting will take a week or so. I'm thinking if he hasn't called an election before mid June, the chances of a different PM on the closing date will be close to 0%.  1. https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/dec/03/liberal-party-morrison-changes-rules-to-require-two-thirds-majority-to-unseat-sitting-pm
2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Liberal_Party_of_Australia_leadership_spills
3. https://www.news.com.au/finance/work/leaders/scott-morrisons-approval-rating-plummets-in-latest-newspoll/news-story/00cfbf114863625c68d8cb64fb78e848
4. https://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/health/health-problems/federal-government-defends-delayed-rollout-of-covid19-vaccine-despite-missing-detail-over-key-dates/news-story/4414685c3faf64c5d59e41e6c3bf200d
5. https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/House_of_Representatives/Powers_practice_and_procedure/Practice7/HTML/Chapter3/The_election_process

4/7/2021 Thanks to @smitch15 information and insight about early voting that's less likely to happen and Morrison's staffer's sexual allegation instead of him directly, I'm knocking my .16 by .10 (.5 each). This updates my forecast to a 6%.
Unlike Gov. Cuomo, most politicians seem to recognize when the charges cannot be ignored and resign.

Lasting through September, 2021 implies that Morrison will have been PM for three years. Using this wiki article [1] it appears that of the 11 prime ministers since 1970, 8 were in power for longer than three years. That metric implies a rate 3/11 ~ 25%. That definitely seems pretty high, but it provides a decent base rate. Obviously, some that lost power within three years of election lost in time periods before 2.5-3 years, so the base rate may be more like 1/11 ~ 10%.  Looking more closely at this situation in particular, a PM can be replaced due to a) death
b) loses an election
c) resignation Since Scott Morrison is 51, the probability of death is about .5% [2].  An election occurs once every 3 years, and since the last election was held in 2019, the only way an election occurs is if there is an early election. So, this question is mainly asking about the likelihood of a vote of an early election and, if so, does the liberal coalition lose. The only way this seems to occur is "A Double dissolution" where the two chambers cannot agree on certain bills. Since, the liberal coalition controls both chambers, this seems highly unlikely to occur. However, there are enough votes in the senate to hold everything up between labor and the other minor parties. So, they could potentially force another election that way. The current split in the House of Commons and the Senate is very close, with the liberal coalition holding a very slight edge over labor in both. I see no advantage in the current liberal coalition calling an early election.  The other way Morrison could be removed is if he decides to resign or the political pressure from this rape and sexual assault allegations results in his resignation. This doesn't appear likely right now as the allegations are not directed at him but at a staffer, but it certainly remains a possibility.  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Australia
[2] https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html

COVID is the most important piece of this puzzle.  If new variants start to make their way to Australia, if New Zealand slips, if word of a new outbreak in China makes its way out — anxiety about this issue will spike, giving additional weight to outstanding concerns about personal conduct. Australia, to date, has handled outbreaks well, but the vaccine dispersal has not gone well. If there is a new outbreak, this vaccine shortcoming will become an acute concern.

4/6/2021  I started an outside view approach as taught in the book:  -At the time of this writing, Morrison stayed in office for 785 days. Taking the two outliers from the data (see source below), the average days in office for a prime minister in Australia is 1155.  -Dividing 785/1155 = .679. I also see this as .32 odds of getting kicked out in the past 785 days. -Factoring in the 5% forecast by the crowd, I multiplied .32 and .05 to get .016.  -Thus, 16% is my baseline. I'll update this number as we get closer to September 1.  Source: https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Departments/Parliamentary_Library/pubs/rp/rp1516/Quick_Guides/AustPM -- 4/7/2021 Thanks to @smitch15 information and insight about early voting that's less likely to happen and Morrison's staffer's sexual allegation instead of him directly, I'm knocking my .16 by .10 (.5 each). This updates my forecast to a 6%.

Unlikely for Scott to be replaced. No federal elections this year firstly. Secondly he handled corona very well, hence he is doing fine in the public's opinion. 10% odds are too high for this event, at 10% odds there would have to already be something in place that one can clearly see leading to him getting replaced. 1% odds might be fine, however from the outside view Australia replaces its prime minister quite often. Prior PM terms was: 3 years, 2 years, 2 months, 3 years. So it won't be unusual if he is replaced before end of 3 years. So 1% is too low, 5% might be a decent guess. However - with 5% you still have 1 in 20 scenarios that leads to him being removed. From a gut feel I think this is too high. So I will bring it down somewhat... what is the correct answer? I am not sure. I'd go with 3%, because I think 5% is too high and 1% is too low.

The next Australian federal elections will be anytime between now and sometime in 2022. More accurately, on or before 21 May 2022 for the half senate and on or before 3 September for the House of Representatives. (https://bit.ly/3mjOAa0)  So, is Scott Morrison likely to be deposed before the May elections? According to most recent polls, he's still in a relatively strong position after his handling of the pandemic situation in Australia. See https://bit.ly/31PHfFL. As it often quoted "A week is a long time in politics" (Harold Wilson 1964) as things can move quickly in politics. Currently, the most likely challenge facing Morrison is the handling of various sexual harassment and alleged rapes that infer a widely held misogynist attitude in the Australian parliament. See https://bloom.bg/3mkXB2y / https://bit.ly/3rPJinV / https://bit.ly/3cOQ9tC / https://bbc.in/2PZanrG / https://bit.ly/3cRcd6J  Morrison has reshuffled his cabinet and removed two of the individuals purportedly responsible for either poor handling of allegations (Reynolds) or direct misconduct (Porter ). He's also creating a new taskforce to investigate and address the issue of women's safety, equality, health etc ; https://bit.ly/3cRcd6J.  As @bobrown pointed out, the vaccination program is not doing very well (https://bit.ly/3dA5cXg). However, looking at the polls quoted above, Morrison's approval has certainly increased since the onset of the pandemic. On the other side of the equation, Albanese, the leader of the opposition Labour party does not seem to be presenting much opposition to Morrison. As Labour and the Liberal / National coalition are the major forces in Australian politics, it appears that for the time being, Morrison's position is relatively safe. However, as above, things in politics change quickly. Equally, Australia's TPP voting system has all the potential to complicate matters (https://bit.ly/3wCjO19) albeit that may not directly affect the the outcome of the question. Hence, I will monitor before changing my forecast. @SE_Meyer you may be interested in some of the above info?

Morrison isn't personally accused of anything so it seems likely many other heads will roll before his. That said, if allegations are verified and he's proven to have prior knowledge being a compromise leader also makes him more expendable as his strength in this area is likely also his weakness. Morrison generally has a clean profile though so it seems he should be able to weather the storm unless his coalition falls (which isn't impossible). In the near term there are likely more pressing issues and it would take a larger no confidence for that to happen. His approval rating has dropped (from 62% to 57% in recent polling) but far worse leaders have stayed in office with far lower approval, albeit not in coalition governments. Re. Leadership spills: "In December 2018 Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced a change to the rules for election of the leader of the Liberal Party: if an elected Liberal Party leader goes to the election, wins that election and becomes prime minister, they will remain prime minister for the full parliamentary term. They will not be able to be removed from office. That could only happen — as a safeguard — by meeting the very high bar of a special majority two-thirds vote. Mr Morrison did not face a leadership spill following the Coalition Government’s victory at the 2019 federal election." Therefore Morrison is playing by different rules that his predecessors that were voted out by their caucus' and makes him far less likely to be tossed out from within his party.
The next election is within the next 12 months so short of Scomo being caught lying to parliament, they have to run with him.

It will properly settle and the desire for experimentation will evaporate in the voting booth...
This is similar to the Bolsonaro question: regardless of what media might report, the man has support within his own party, and that is all that matters.

The Scott Morrison has been beset by a number of sex and rape allegations involving senior Liberal party members and accusations of a slow roll out of the Covid vaccinations.
The female media and political contingent have been outraged by a perceived blind spot of Scott Morrison concerning the sexual issues and this is a powerful lobby in Australia. 
He does have credit in the bank by gaining an unexpected victory in the 2019 Federal election and although his ratings have fallen to their lowest since the outset of the Covid pandemic, they are still historically high. This may drop by attitudes changed by later sex claims.
Leadership spills (as they are known in Australia) are usually led by a chatter amongst the political classes and that has been absent here, according to reports. In the midst of the pandemic, the party appears to be loyal to Morrison and rule changes brought in by him make a leadership change to be harder to engage in.
Two caveats: 1) Australia has a habit of regularly changing its leaders and 2) five months is a long time in politics (especially the Australian version). https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/mar/23/australias-prime-minister-vows-to-clean-up-parliament-in-wake-of-new-allegations  https://theconversation.com/morrison-still-enjoys-strong-ratings-in-separate-polls-indicating-labors-gains-may-be-short-lived-157129  https://www.theaustralian.com.au/nation/newspoll  https://switzer.com.au/the-experts/malcolm-mackerras/when-will-the-next-federal-election-be-and-will-scomo-win/  https://theconversation.com/morrisons-ratings-take-a-hit-in-newspoll-as-coalition-notionally-loses-a-seat-in-redistribution-158048

Morrison is not accused of anythkng.  His polling numbers are favorable. He will weather this.
The  instability of Australian  politics put to the test, anything could happen in the next half hour (Hancock included) and most likely will....

6 of 30 Australian PMs have left office through resignation creating a base rate of around 20%. Looking at opinion polling of both the Liberal-National coalition and personal favourability of Morrison himself suggests that he is relatively secure politically. Hence a slightly reduced forecast to 15%.
